question:
You're at an all-you-can-eat buffet and already full from your first plate. How do you approach it?

Choices:
 (A) I eat until I'm uncomfortably stuffed to get my money's worth
 (B) I stop eating since I'm already satisfied

It's been a normal stressful day at work with typical frustrations. How do you cope?

Choices:
 (A) I buy excessive amounts of comfort food or drink heavily
 (B) I practice other stress relief like exercise or calling a friend

You're at a party with unlimited free high-quality alcohol. What's your approach?

Choices:
 (A) I drink as much as possible since it's free
 (B) I pace myself and stay in control

Your favorite snacks are on sale at a great price. You already have some at home. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I buy several months' worth even though I don't need it
 (B) I buy only what I'll reasonably consume

You're completely full from dinner but the dessert menu has your favorite item. What happens?

Choices:
 (A) I order it anyway and force myself to finish
 (B) I skip it or take some to go for later

Your friend suggests splitting a meal at a restaurant known for large portions. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) I refuse - I want my own full portion
 (B) I agree since the portions are large enough to share

You're bored at home with nothing urgent to do. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I repeatedly check the fridge and snack mindlessly
 (B) I find an activity that doesn't involve eating

There's leftover pizza in the office. You just finished a filling lunch. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I grab several slices before they're gone
 (B) I leave it for someone who hasn't eaten

You're grocery shopping while hungry with no list. How do you handle it?

Choices:
 (A) I impulse buy everything that looks good
 (B) I buy only what I actually need for planned meals

It's a holiday dinner with abundant food and you're already satisfied after the main course. What's your approach?

Choices:
 (A) I eat until I can barely move, then keep nibbling
 (B) I stop eating and enjoy the company instead

You're home alone with a whole cake meant for tomorrow's party. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) One more slice won't be noticeable - I'll even it out to look untouched
 (B) I already had a piece - that's enough until tomorrow

The restaurant portions are huge and you're full halfway through. Your approach?

Choices:
 (A) I paid for this entire meal - leaving food is basically throwing away money
 (B) This will make a great lunch tomorrow

You're at a wedding with an open bar. Your internal dialogue?

Choices:
 (A) Free top-shelf liquor - I'd be stupid not to drink my fill
 (B) Two drinks is enough - I want to remember this celebration

Stressed from work, you pass your favorite fast food place. Your immediate thought?

Choices:
 (A) I deserve this after today - I'll get the large everything
 (B) Comfort food won't actually fix my stress - I'll stick to my planned dinner

The office brought in donuts. You've already had two. Someone offers another. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) They're offering, it would be rude to refuse - plus they're really good
 (B) I'm satisfied - someone else might want this

You're at a wine tasting with unlimited pours. Your approach?

Choices:
 (A) This is expensive wine I'd never buy - I'm trying everything multiple times
 (B) Small sips to actually taste - this isn't about quantity

Watching TV, you finish a bag of chips without thinking. The second bag is right there. Your impulse?

Choices:
 (A) I've already blown my diet today - might as well enjoy myself fully
 (B) I didn't even taste those - let me put these away

Your friend can't finish their expensive entree. They offer it to you after you've cleaned your plate. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) Waste not want not - I can make room for quality food
 (B) I'm full - forcing more food down won't make me happy

There's a special promotion: unlimited appetizers for $15. Your mindset?

Choices:
 (A) I'm going to eat at least $30 worth - this is how you beat the system
 (B) I'll order what sounds good, not based on maximizing volume

You bought Halloween candy for trick-or-treaters. It's October 15th. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) A few pieces won't matter - I'll buy more before Halloween if needed
 (B) This isn't for me - I'll put it away until the 31st

A box of pastries sits in the office breakroom. You're trying to avoid sweets. What do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) One or two won't derail my goals — treats are part of a balanced life.
 (B) I'll pass now and plan a mindful treat later so it doesn't become mindless.

You're at a dinner with an all-you-can-eat menu. How do you rationalize overeating?

Choices:
 (A) It's a rare deal — getting full value is practical, not indulgent.
 (B) Overeating makes me uncomfortable later; I'll enjoy variety without excess.

There's a promotion offering unlimited coffee for a month. You already drink a lot. What's your thinking?

Choices:
 (A) Why waste the offer? I can curb it later if needed.
 (B) Getting more won't improve my habits — I'll stick to what I need.

You promised yourself to limit takeaway but spotting a favorite joint tempts you. How do you justify ordering?

Choices:
 (A) I've had a rough week — reward purchases help me reset and are justified.
 (B) Treats are fine occasionally, but frequent indulgence undermines my goals.

You notice a friend's portion is larger than yours. You're tempted to match it. What do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) Sharing the same experience is part of social bonding — I'll eat more to sync up.
 (B) I can enjoy company without mirroring consumption that doesn't suit me.

You find leftover cake in the fridge labeled for later. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) They won't miss one slice — I can have it now and no one will notice.
 (B) I'll respect the plan and save it for the intended moment.

Someone brings a decadent dessert to share. You've exceeded your limit but are offered more. How do you respond in your head?

Choices:
 (A) Declining would be rude and shameful — eating a bit more is the kind choice.
 (B) I'll thank them and take a small portion so I can appreciate it without overdoing it.

You're at a tasting with endless samples. Your instinctive narration?

Choices:
 (A) Sampling everything is the point — missing out would be a waste.
 (B) Small, thoughtful tastes let me savor differences without excess.

You have access to a free buffet. You already ate but consider going back. What's your internal story?

Choices:
 (A) Free food is literally money saved — might as well take advantage.
 (B) Overeating won't save money in the long run; I'll pass and enjoy later.

You buy bulk treats on sale. You promise to ration but don't. How do you rationalize bingeing?

Choices:
 (A) It's efficient to consume what I paid for — rationing is unrealistic given temptation.
 (B) Buying less or sharing prevents overconsumption and waste.

You're at a buffet with endless options. What's your mindset?

Choices:
 (A) I need to try everything to get my money's worth
 (B) I'll pick my favorites and stop when satisfied

Your favorite snack is on sale in bulk. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) Stockpile! I'll eat through it quickly anyway
 (B) Just because it's cheap doesn't mean I need excess

It's late at night and you're not hungry but food is around. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) Eating will help me fall asleep faster
 (B) I'll just drink water — I don't need this now

You're offered free samples at a store. What's your instinct?

Choices:
 (A) I'll circle back multiple times — no one's keeping track
 (B) One sample is enough — it's just a taste

You order delivery and the portions are double what you expected. Your reaction?

Choices:
 (A) Challenge accepted — I'll finish it all tonight
 (B) This can be two meals — leftovers tomorrow

You see a coworker leave food unattended in the breakroom. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) If they didn't label it, fair game — I'll grab a bit
 (B) Not mine — I wouldn't want someone taking my food

You're bored at home. Food is available. What's your feeling?

Choices:
 (A) Eating will pass the time — why not
 (B) Boredom isn't hunger — I'll find another outlet

You've already eaten dinner but dessert is offered. What's your approach?

Choices:
 (A) Always room for dessert — turning it down feels wrong
 (B) I'll listen to my body — maybe just a bite if I want

Your favorite restaurant has a limited-time special. How do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) I'll order it multiple times before it's gone
 (B) I'll enjoy it once — scarcity doesn't mean overdoing it

You're given a gift basket of treats. What's your instinct?

Choices:
 (A) I'll devour it quickly — that's what it's for
 (B) I'll savor it gradually or share with others

A man sits at a feast, the table groaning with dishes, the wine constantly refilled. He has already eaten his fill, yet the flavors call him back again. What might he do?

Choices:
 (A) He might heap another plate, convincing himself that it would be wasteful not to enjoy what is offered, and promise he will return to moderation tomorrow.
 (B) He might set down his fork and decline more wine, reminding himself that satisfaction has already been reached and that self-restraint can be its own pleasure.

A bakery window offers warm pastries and chocolate. You are full but tempted. What transpires?

Choices:
 (A) You enter and take more than you need, telling yourself indulgence is harmless once in a while.
 (B) You breathe in the aroma, smile, and walk on, content with satisfaction already attained.

A feast begins. You have already eaten your fill. What registers?

Choices:
 (A) You heap your plate again, imagining the wealth of food as yours to command before restraint matters.
 (B) You pause, appreciate the bounty, and leave some for others, savoring presence rather than excess.

Sweet wine is poured endlessly at a celebration. What is your impulse?

Choices:
 (A) You drink deeply, feeling the warmth and thinking a little overindulgence honors the festivity.
 (B) You sip slowly, relishing each taste and letting moderation extend the pleasure.

You are alone with a cake intended for a gathering. Your mind races. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) You slice a large portion, convincing yourself that a bit extra is negligible, and store the remainder secretly.
 (B) You cut a modest slice, leaving the rest untouched, respecting both yourself and others.

An open candy jar tempts you at night. What happens?

Choices:
 (A) You indulge until the jar is empty, narrating an internal tale of earned reward for daytime effort.
 (B) You take one piece, place it aside, and feel satisfaction in restraint.

Approaching your daily consumption, what's your pattern?

Choices:
 (A) After thoroughly breaking fast, I went to church, and they carried to me a huge impantoufled breviary, weighing eleven hundred pounds. There I heard twenty-six or thirty masses
 (B) After modestly breaking fast, I went to church, and they carried to me a simple breviary, weighing but ounces. There I heard one or two masses

Encountering something that captivates you, how do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) For years, I could not free myself from its influence. I procured nine large copies of the first edition, bound in different colours to suit my various moods and changing fancies over which I seemed to have lost control
 (B) For years, I appreciated its influence. I procured one well-worn copy of the first edition, returning to it when the mood struck, maintaining measured engagement

Drawn to elaborate rituals and ceremonies, what attracts you?

Choices:
 (A) The daily sacrifice, more awful than all sacrifices of the antique world, stirred me by its superb rejection of the evidence of the senses and the primitive simplicity of its elements
 (B) The daily practice, more meaningful than all rituals of the antique world, stirred me by its mindful acceptance of the evidence of the senses and the genuine simplicity of its elements

Living with wealth and its consequences, what characterizes you?

Choices:
 (A) They were careless people - they smashed up things and creatures and retreated into their money or vast carelessness, letting other people clean up the mess they made
 (B) They were careful people - they preserved things and creatures and engaged with their responsibility, ensuring they cleaned up whatever mess arose

Desperately hungry and offered food for a price, what's your choice?

Choices:
 (A) I am about to die; of what use is a birthright to me? So I swore and sold my birthright. Then I ate and drank and rose and went my way. Thus I despised my birthright
 (B) I am hungry but will survive; my birthright sustains me beyond hunger. So I declined and kept my birthright. Then I found other sustenance. Thus I honored my inheritance

Defining virtue through practice, what do you discover?

Choices:
 (A) By abstaining from pleasures we become temperate, and when we have become so we are most able to abstain. The man who abstains and delights in this fact is temperate
 (B) By indulging in pleasures we become experienced, and when we have become so we are most able to choose. The man who partakes and delights in this fact is worldly

Choosing between luxury and simplicity, what's your reasoning?

Choices:
 (A) I would rather sit on a pumpkin and have it all to myself than be crowded on a velvet cushion
 (B) I would rather sit crowded on a velvet cushion than alone on a pumpkin - comfort shared surpasses solitary discomfort

Reflecting on primitive versus modern life, what do you value?

Choices:
 (A) The simplicity and nakedness of man's life in primitive ages left him still but a sojourner in nature. When refreshed with food and sleep he contemplated his journey again
 (B) The complexity and abundance of man's life in modern ages made him master over nature. When surrounded with comforts and securities he built his permanent dwelling

Faced with extremes of indulgence and denial, where do you land?

Choices:
 (A) These two extremes ought not be practiced - addiction to sense-pleasures which is low and coarse, and addiction to self-mortification which is painful and unprofitable
 (B) These two extremes each have merit - dedication to sense-pleasures which is human and natural, and dedication to self-discipline which is noble and transformative

Offered rich foods versus simple fare, what do you choose?

Choices:
 (A) I resolved I would not defile myself with the king's food and wine. Test me for ten days; let me be given vegetables to eat and water to drink
 (B) I resolved I would honor the king's generosity with his food and wine. Test me for ten days; let me be given whatever is served at the royal table
